newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Asia Naphtha/Mogas- Mixed after Thai shutdowns.
newsitem.headline: Asia Naphtha/Mogas- Mixed after Thai shutdowns.

text.p: Prices in the gasoline market were stable despite mixed talks on market direction after some refinery shutdowns in Thailand, traders said on Thursday.
Traders differed in views on market direction after the shutdowns in Thailand with some saying routine maintenance would not affect the market while others said supplies would fall further.
Bangchak Petroleum Plc closed a 40,000 barrels-per-day crude distillation unit (CDU) for a 2-week scheduled maintenance in the second half of January.
At around the same time Star Petroleum Refinery Co shutdown part of its 130,000-bpd refining capacity for about one-week, the source said.
It's mainly a sellers' market at this moment as supplies are quite tight, said one bullish trader.
"There is no sign of supply easing and supplies should continue tightening following recent shutdowns," said a major of gasoline
However, trading interest remained thin, they added.
Gasoline 92-octane was bid at $27.20 per barrel for lifting March 4-8 and 97-octane was offered at $28.6 per barrel for lifting March 10-14, little changed from Wednesday's levels, traders said.
On Wednesday, an European major sold a crago of unleaded 97-octane gasoline on Wednesday to a U.S. major at $28.70 per barrel lifting between February 27 and March 3.
Naphtha was little changed despite crude's fall in thin talk with naphtha March swaps sliding 20-15 cents per barrel to $23.50/$23.75.
MTH FOB SIN BUY/SELL PREV BUY/SELL
